bug.author: magnusja
bug.summary: [tune] seems to leak memory during checkpoint/pausing trials
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h3>What is the problem?</denchmark-h>
Ray seems to slowly leak memory over the course of tuning via PBT. Training is run in inside a k3s node (single node Kubernetes) with nvidia-docker and docker as container runtime (instead of containerd). Screenshot if pod memory usage (grafana): <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/99815787-10d70280-2b4b-11eb-80aa-7803b63a102e.png></denchmark-link>
where blue is ray 1.0.0 and purple ray 1.0.1 Output of ray memory ray 1.0.0 <denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/magnusja/f4f4eb73678103c3438139543c15685e>https://gist.github.com/magnusja/f4f4eb73678103c3438139543c15685e</denchmark-link>
ray 1.0.1 <denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/magnusja/b9e381ada542a471dd90b95dce3f02d1>https://gist.github.com/magnusja/b9e381ada542a471dd90b95dce3f02d1</denchmark-link>
What I am not sure is if the object size from ray memory somehow aligns with the increase in usage in grafana. The objects seems to be quite small? Is the object size measured in bytes? It also seems that ray 1.0.1 is not leaking as much as 1.0.0? Ray version and other system information (Python version, TensorFlow version, OS): ray: 1.0.0 and 1.0.1 python: 3.8.6 tensorflow: 2.3.1 pytorch: 1.6.0 <denchmark-h:h3>Reproduction (REQUIRED)</denchmark-h>
Unfortunately, this problems occurs inside a very complex project. I tried a much simpler setup but then I had the feeling it is not leaking any memory, but it just might be a lot slower. What Ii noticed is that the complex projects metric to guide PBT does not improve steadily and is sometimes zero or NaN for multiple iterations. Not sure if that has something to do with it.

comments.comment: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/magnusja>@magnusja</denchmark-link> this is interesting, thanks for reporting this issue. What happens when you let it continue training (i.e., many hours)? Does it oom?

Yes it does get killed at 100GB (current pod limit), but I also have seen it getting killed at 150GB. Last run which got killed today: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/99888963-1f0f4680-2c51-11eb-9267-b0eb42e37150.jpg></denchmark-link>
ray memory a couple of hours before OOM: <denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/magnusja/0bd1849b42d7e6cd940505e3c5b779f2>https://gist.github.com/magnusja/0bd1849b42d7e6cd940505e3c5b779f2</denchmark-link>
Anything else I could do to debug this?

I think this is good, I thought I fixed this earlier a month ago but I guess we still have some issues. I’ll take a look at this later this week and will report progress in this thread!
Is this a blocker for you right now? <denchmark-link:#>…</denchmark-link>
On Sat, Nov 21, 2020 at 2:29 PM magnus ***@***.***> wrote: Yes it does get killed at 100GB (current pod limit), but I also have seen it getting killed at 150GB.
Last run which got killed today: [image: Anmerkung 2020-11-21 232612] <https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/99888963-1f0f4680-2c51-11eb-9267-b0eb42e37150.jpg>
ray memory a couple of hours before killing: https://gist.github.com/magnusja/0bd1849b42d7e6cd940505e3c5b779f2
Anything else I could do to debug this?
— You are receiving this because you were assigned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#12208 (comment)>, or unsubscribe <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABCRZZJEC7XDNJTFXVBGROTSRA5L3ANCNFSM4T44UJEA> .

Yeah, unfortunately, it is. I tried 0.8.6 but it seems that I am having the same issue there as well? <denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/magnusja/6ce14e08a93864fed015bc4931877c63>https://gist.github.com/magnusja/6ce14e08a93864fed015bc4931877c63</denchmark-link>
I think this was working fine at some point with ray 0.8.6, so maybe the error is in my code somewhere or the problem really is because training is not really improving performance? That would be the two differences I can currently think of compared to beginning of the year. But I am happy to take a look as well. I will use this as reference point to dig in: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ray-project/ray/commit/ee85cb31a50b00ef439e3eca4f601135753f03f0>ee85cb3</denchmark-link>

Quick update from my side. A simple seems to improve the situation. See here <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ray-project/ray/pull/12418/files>https://github.com/ray-project/ray/pull/12418/files</denchmark-link>
Ray nightly from Nov 24 <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/100340473-8de6f980-2fdb-11eb-88c1-279f4883a52d.PNG></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/magnusja/f0cec405ace330ce8a25047646cbd0e5>https://gist.github.com/magnusja/f0cec405ace330ce8a25047646cbd0e5</denchmark-link>
I tried this with 1.0.1 as well just to rule out that the nightly somehow fixes the problem <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/100340615-c090f200-2fdb-11eb-88da-7d3840ab2a9e.PNG></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/magnusja/bfd4c861152b1446624e3cae9bfc0305>https://gist.github.com/magnusja/bfd4c861152b1446624e3cae9bfc0305</denchmark-link>
In both cases ray memory shows there are 10 to 14 checkpoints and it is not increasing constantly as before. This is also noticeable in the RAM usage in both cases although it seems that RAM usage decreased drastically for the nightly version. Unfortunately, it still seems to be leaking memory in both cases, although a lot slower for the nightly version. It seems that the call to gc.collect() removes unused checkpoints from the object store. My guess would be that the automatic gc only frees objects if they allocate a decent amount of memory. As the reference to the object store is quite small it never gets evicted automatically. The python garbage collector unfortunately does not know that the object in the ray object store is actually quite large. The only question remaining: why does it still seem to leak memory? But maybe this is also a problem in my code. The configuration for tune.run we are using: <denchmark-code>checkpoint_frequency = 1 keep_checkpoints_num = 100000 # we had problems with checkpoints being deleted but used in a trial afterwards leading to a crash (no such file or directory) pertubation_interval = 1 resample_probability = 0.25 quantile_fraction = 0.5 population_size = 8 </denchmark-code>
We are using PBT scheduler. Direct comparsion between nightly and 1.0.1 where blue is nightly: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/100341701-35b0f700-2fdd-11eb-9217-b4dc42d93890.PNG></denchmark-link>

Actually looking at ray 1.0.1 w/ vs w/o they dont look too different. I will try nightly w/o to see if the nightly maybe has some effect on this as well. <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/99888963-1f0f4680-2c51-11eb-9267-b0eb42e37150.jpg></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/100340615-c090f200-2fdb-11eb-88da-7d3840ab2a9e.PNG></denchmark-link>

Hmm <denchmark-link:https://github.com/magnusja>@magnusja</denchmark-link> what happens when you set the object_store_memory in ray start (or ray.init)? I suspect somehow we're not detecting the virtual memory available on the pod.

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/richardliaw>@richardliaw</denchmark-link>
sorry for the super late response. So I think I played around with that option, but it seemed to have no effect at all. I tried the lru_evict=True as well. But shouldn't I get an ObjectStoreFull only setting the memory size? I think it pre 1.0 it was syaing something like object store size around 25GB but it recognized the whole 256GB ram of the machine. That is also what I see in the dashboard currently. it says usage 71GB of 256GB. The training I started last week (1.0.1 w/ ) is still running, even though memory usage was increasing. This is the usage for the last 7 days: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1659457/100939813-3c68ce00-34f7-11eb-8cd4-cef4d0d5fd90.png></denchmark-link>
This is definitely the longest run. Usually it crashed after something like 3 days, latest. But I am still a little skeptical, as it comes pretty close to the memory limit. I have seen it using 99,2GB of 100GB. So maybe you are considering the pod memory limit, and with the gc.collect() memory is freed as it is supposed to?

Well, my theory was that somehow it was recognizing the wrong memory limit (machine instead of pod), leading to an assumption that it had more memory working space than needed. However, maybe it is an incorrect theory. This result that you posted definitely looks promising to me though!

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/magnusja>@magnusja</denchmark-link> I think this might be a separate issue because the raylet fails? If so, should we then mark the OOM issue as fixed and open a separate issue for this new failure?

Yes lets close this for now. I think PyTorch dataloder was stalling because of some weird deadlock similar to this: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/1355>pytorch/pytorch#1355</denchmark-link>
Setting the opencv threads and generally limiting the dataloders to 16 instead of 32 seems to have improved the situation. Will report back if not. Thanks a lot.
